abstract_sentences.1: Understanding common entities and their attributes is a primary requirement for any system that comprehends natural language.
abstract_sentences.2: In order to enable learning about common entities, we introduce a novel machine comprehension task, GuessTwo: given a short paragraph comparing different aspects of two realworld semantically-similar entities, a system should guess what those entities are.
abstract_sentences.3: Accomplishing this task requires deep language understanding which enables inference, connecting each comparison paragraph to different levels of knowledge about world entities and their attributes.
abstract_sentences.4: So far we have crowdsourced a dataset of more than 14K comparison paragraphs comparing entities from a variety of categories such as fruits and animals.
abstract_sentences.5: We have designed two schemes for evaluation: open-ended, and binary-choice prediction.
abstract_sentences.6: For benchmarking further progress in the task, we have collected a set of paragraphs as the test set on which human can accomplish the task with an accuracy of 94.2% on open-ended prediction.
abstract_sentences.7: We have implemented various models for tackling the task, ranging from semantic-driven to neural models.
abstract_sentences.8: The semantic-driven approach outperforms the neural models, however, the results indicate that the task is very challenging across the models.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1084  1 Introduction  In the past few years, there has been great progress on core NLP tasks (e.g., parsing and part of speech tagging) which has renewed interest in primary language learning tasks which require text under-
standing and reasoning, such as machine comprehension (Schoenick et al., 2016; Hermann et al., 2015; Rajpurkar et al., 2016; Mostafazadeh et al., 2016).
body_sentences.2: Our question is how far have we got in learning basic concepts of the world through language comprehension.
body_sentences.3: If we look at the large body of work on extracting knowledge from unstructured corpora, we will see that they often lack some very basic pieces of information.
body_sentences.4: For example, let us focus on the basic concept of apple, the fruit.
body_sentences.5: What do the state-of-the-art systems and resources know about an apple?
body_sentences.6: None of the state-of-the-art knowledge bases (Speer and Havasi, 2012; Carlson et al., 2010; Fader et al., 2011) include much precise information about the fact that apples have an edible skin, vary from sweet to sour, are round, and relatively the same size of a fist.
body_sentences.7: Moreover, there is no clear approach on how to extract such information, if any, from trained word embeddings.
body_sentences.8: This paper focuses on how we can automatically learn about various attributes of such generic entities in the world.
body_sentences.9: A key observation motivating this work is that we can learn more detail about objects when they are compared to other similar objects.
body_sentences.10: When we compare things we often contrast, that is, we count their similarities along with their dissimilarities.
body_sentences.11: This results in covering the primary attributes and aspects of objects.
body_sentences.12: As humans, we tend to recall and mention the difference between things (say green skin vs. red skin in apples) as opposed to absolute measures (say the existence of skin).
body_sentences.13: Interestingly, there is evidence that human knowledge is structured by semantic similarity and the relations among objects are defined by their relative perceptual and conceptual properties, such as their form, function, behavior, and environment (Collins and Loftus, 1975; Tversky and Gati, 1978; Cree and Mcrae, 2003).
body_sentences.14:
Our idea is to leverage comparison as a way of naturally learning
906
about common world concepts and their specific attributes.
body_sentences.15: Comparison, where we name the similarities and differences between things, is a unique cognitive ability in humans1 which requires memorizing facts, experiencing things and integration of concepts of the world (Hazlitt, 1933).
body_sentences.16: It is clear that developing AI systems that are capable of comprehending comparison is crucial.
body_sentences.17: In this paper, in order to enable learning through comparison, we introduce a new language comprehension task which requires understanding different attributes of basic entities that are being compared.
body_sentences.18: The contributions of this paper are as follows: (1) To equip learning about common entities through comparison comprehension, we have crowdsourced a dataset of more than 14K comparison paragraphs comparing entities from nine broad categories (Section 2).
body_sentences.19: This resource will be expanded over time and will be released to the public.
body_sentences.20: (2) We introduce a novel task called GuessTwo, in which given a short paragraph comparing two entities, a system should guess what the two things are.
body_sentences.22: To make systematic benchmarking on the task possible, we vet a collection of comparison paragraphs to obtain a test set on which human performs with an accuracy 94.2%.
body_sentences.23: (3) We present a host of neural approaches and a novel semantic-driven model for tackling the GuessTwo task (Sections 4, 5).
body_sentences.24: Our experiments show that the semantic approach outperforms the neural models.
body_sentences.25: The results strongly suggest that closing the gap between system and human performances requires richer semantic processing (Section 6).
body_sentences.26: We hope that this work will establish a new base for a machine comprehension test that requires systems to go beyond information extraction and towards levels of performing basic reasoning.

2 Data Collection  To enable learning about common entities, we aimed to create a dataset which meets the following goals:

body_sentences.32: The comparisons in the dataset should involve everyday non-technical concepts, making their comprehension easy and commonsense for a human.
body_sentences.33: After many experiments with scraping existing Web resources, we decided to crowdsource the comparison paragraphs using Amazon Mechanical Turk2 (Mturk).
body_sentences.34: We prompt the crowd workers as follows: “Your task is to compare two given items in one simple language paragraph so that a knowledgeable person who reads it can guess what the two things are”.
body_sentences.35: The workers were instructed to compare only the major and well-known aspects of the two entities.
body_sentences.36: We also asked them to use X and Y for anonymously referring to the two entities.
body_sentences.37: Table 1 shows three examples of our crowdsourced comparison paragraphs.
body_sentences.38: As these examples show, the paragraphs are very contentful and rich in comparison which meets our initial goals in the dataset creation.
body_sentences.40: The choice of the two entities which should be compared against each other plays a key role in the quality of the collected dataset.
body_sentences.41: It is evident that naturally, we compare two things which are semantically similar, yet have some dissimilarities3, such as jam and jelly.
body_sentences.42: Given the goals of our task, we experimented with concrete nouns which share a common taxonomy class.
body_sentences.43: We choose semantic classes which have at least five well-known entities.
body_sentences.44: So far, we have covered nine broad categories as shown in Figure 2, with 21 subcategories shown in Figure 3.
body_sentences.45: We use Wikipedia item categories and the WordNet (Miller, 1995) ontology for identifying entities from each subcategory.
body_sentences.46: Then, we choose the most common entities by looking up their frequency on Google Web 1T N-grams4.
body_sentences.47: We manually inspected the frequency-filtered list to make sure that the entities are rather easy to describe without getting technical.
body_sentences.48: Given the list of entities, we paired each entity with at most five and at least three other entities from the same subcategory.

body_sentences.53: Our task of free-form writing is trickier than many other tasks such as tagging on Mturk.
body_sentences.54: To instruct the non-expert workers, we designed a qualification test on Mturk in which the workers had to judge whether or not a given paragraph is acceptable according to our criteria.
body_sentences.55: We used three carefully selected paragraphs to be a part of the qualification test.
body_sentences.56: Moreover, to further ensure the quality of the submissions, one of our team members qualitatively browsed through the submissions and gave the workers detailed feedback before approving their paragraphs.
body_sentences.57: For each pair of entities, we collected eight comparison paragraphs from different workers.
body_sentences.58: Given that different workers have different perspectives on what the major aspects to be compared are, collecting multiple paragraphs helps further enriching our dataset.
body_sentences.59: We constrained the paragraphs to be at least 250 characters and at most 850 characters.

body_sentences.66: In order to enable benchmarking on the task, we assessed the quality of a random sample of GuessTwo paragraphs as follows: we show the paragraph to three human workers on Mturk and ask them to guess what the two things are.
body_sentences.67: Then, we choose 520 paragraphs for which all three workers have made exactly correct guesses for both entities.
body_sentences.68: The test set will also be expanded along with the further data collection.
body_sentences.69: We divided the rest of the GuessTwo dataset into training and validation sets, with a 90%/10% split.
body_sentences.70: To ensure that the test set requires some level of basic reasoning, our training set does not share any exact entity pairs with the validation or test set.
body_sentences.71: This further enforces systems to learn about entities indirectly by processing across paragraphs.
body_sentences.72: For instance, as shown in Figure 4, at test time, a system should be able to guess a comparison involving the entities blood orange vs. lemon by having seen comparisons of blood orange vs. tangerine and tangerine vs. lemon.
body_sentences.73: Our dataset will be released to the public through https://omidb.github.io/ guesstwo/.
body_sentences.74: 3 The GuessTwo Task Definition  We define the following two different schemes for the GuessTwo task: • Open-ended GuessTwo.
body_sentences.75: Given a short paragraph P which compares two entities X and Y, guess what the two entities are.
body_sentences.76: The scope of this prediction is the set of all entities appearing in the training dataset.
body_sentences.78: Given a short paragraph P which compares two entities X and Y, and two nominals n1 and n2, choose 0 if n1 = X and n2 = Y, choose 1 otherwise.
body_sentences.79: We speculate that system which can successfully tackle the GuessTwo task, has achieved two major objectives: (1) Has successfully learned the knowledge about entities stored in any form (e.g., continuous-space representation or symbolic) (2) Has a basic natural language understanding capability, using which, it can comprehend a paragraph and access its knowledge.
body_sentences.80: We predict that our training dataset has enough detailed information about entities for learning the required knowledge for tackling the task.
body_sentences.81: Given the design of our dataset, at test time, a system should perform some level of reasoning to go beyond understanding only one paragraph.

body_sentences.96: This model is a sequence-to-sequence generation model (Cho et al., 2014; Sutskever et al., 2014) that maps an input sequence to an output sequence using an encoder-decoder RNN with attention (Bahdanau et al., 2014).

body_sentences.114: 5 Semantic-driven Model  In this Section we present a semantic-driven approach which models the comparison paragraph using semantic features and is capable of performing basic reasoning across paragraphs.
body_sentences.115: 5.1 Representing Paragraphs  The question is, given a comparison paragraph, what is the best representation which can enable further reasoning?
body_sentences.116: The comparison paragraphs often have complex syntactic and semantic structures, which might be challenging for many offthe-shelf NLP tools to process.
body_sentences.117: For instance, consider the sentence X is much sweeter in taste than Y.
body_sentences.118: Although a dependency parser provides a lot of information regarding how the individual words relate grammatically, it does not give us any information regarding how Y’s sweetness (which is elided from the sentence and is implicit) relates to X’s.
body_sentences.119:
As another processing technique, if we use the standard information extraction methods for extracting and representing syntactic triplets (argument1, relation, argument2) (Fader et al., 2014; Etzioni et al., 2011), we will extract a triplet such
6https://code.google.com/archive/p/ word2vec/
as X is sweeter which shares the same shortcomings.
body_sentences.120: Our approach for better representation of comparison paragraphs starts with a broad-coverage semantic parser (Banarescu et al., 2013; Bos, 2008; Allen et al., 2008).
body_sentences.121: A semantic parser maps an input sentence to its formal meaning representation, operating at the generic natural language level.
body_sentences.122: Here we use the TRIPS7 (Allen et al., 2008) broad-coverage semantic parser.
body_sentences.123: TRIPS provides a very rich semantic structure; mainly it provides sense disambiguated deep structures augmented with semantic ontology types.
body_sentences.124: Figure 7 shows an example TRIPS semantic parse.
body_sentences.125: In this graph representation, each node specifies a word in bold along with its corresponding ontology type on its left.
body_sentences.126: The edges in the graph are semantic roles8.
body_sentences.127: As you can see, this semantic parse represents the sentence by decoupling the token ‘both’ and attributing the property of ‘be apple’ to both X and Y.
body_sentences.128: In our comparison paragraphs there are two major types of sentences: • Sentences with Absolute Information.
body_sentences.129: These sentences contain direct information about the entities, such as X is red or Both X and Y are very sweet.
body_sentences.130: From each absolute sentence, we extract frames which describe the absolute attributes of the corresponding entity.
body_sentences.131: We define a frame to be a subgraph of a semantic parse which involves exactly one entity and all of its semantic roles.
body_sentences.132: Relying on the deep semantic features offered by the semantic parser, we perform negation propagation9 and sequence decoupling, among others features.
body_sentences.133: For example, given a sentence which has a sequence, as the one depicted in Figure 7, we perform sequence decoupling and extract the two frames [X Be Apple] and [Y Be Apple].
body_sentences.135: These sentences contain relative information about the two entities, for instance, X is somewhat sweeter thanY.
body_sentences.136: As opposed to the sentences with absolute information, we cannot extract frames from sentences with comparisons directly.
body_sentences.137:
Various properties of entities can be associated with an abstract scale, such as ‘size’ or ‘sweetness’, on which dif-

body_sentences.144: Given a comparison structure such as the one presented in Figure 8, we can extract the information that on the scale of ‘sweetness’ X is higher thanY.
body_sentences.145: It is clear that one can build a large knowledge base of such relations by reading large collections of comparison paragraphs.

As for the open-ended prediction we compute the nominator of the accuracy measure using three various matching methods on both entities: (1) exact-match, (2) subcategory match, (3) broad category match.
body_sentences.162: As Table 3 shows, the semantic model outperforms all the neural models.
body_sentences.163: Moreover, the ILP constraints have been very effective in directing the system in the correct search space.
body_sentences.164: Among the neural models, the Encoder-Decoder RNN model performs noticeably better than other models when matching the subcategory and broad category.
body_sentences.165: According to the exact-matching, neither of the CBOW models could guess any of the two test entities correctly.
body_sentences.166: Overall, it is evident that the end-to-end neural models have not been able to generalize well and learn about the attributes of entities across various training paragraphs.
body_sentences.167: This can be partly due to not being trained on large enough comparison training dataset.
body_sentences.168: The semantic model, however, could outperform the neural models using the same amount of data.
body_sentences.169: To a degree, this is because the semantic model leverages the basic language understanding capabilities offered by the semantic parser.
body_sentences.170: It is also important to note that our semantic approach is not only capable of binary and open-ended prediction, but it also offers two byproducts that can be used as knowledge in a variety of other tasks: (1) a set of the most important absolute information frames which can be chosen based on feature importance in the classification, (2) the partial ordering lattice of entities.
body_sentences.171: Overall, the results strongly suggest that the GuessTwo task is challenging, with the open-ended scheme being the most challenging.
body_sentences.172: There is a wide gap between human and system performance on this task, which makes it a very promising task for the community to pursue.
body_sentences.173: 7 Related Work  The task of Machine Comprehension (MC) has gained a significant attention over the past few years.
body_sentences.174: The major driver for MC has been the publicly available benchmarking datasets.
body_sentences.175: A variety of MC tasks have been introduced in the community (Richardson et al.
body_sentences.176: ; Hermann et al., 2015; Rajpurkar et al., 2016; Hill et al., 2015), in which the system reads a short text and answers a few multiple-choice questions.
body_sentences.177: The reading comprehension involved in these tests ranges from reading a short fictional story (Richardson et al.)
body_sentences.178: to reading a short news article (Hermann et al., 2015).
body_sentences.179: In comparison, in the GuessTwo task the reading comprehension involves reading a short comparison paragraph and one can say the multiple-choice question is the constant What are X and Y?
body_sentences.180: The CNN/DailyMail dataset consists of more than 100K short news articles with the questions automatically created from the bullet-point summaries of the original article.
body_sentences.181: This dataset uses fill-in-the-blank-style questions such as ‘Producer X will not press charges against Jeremy Clarkson’ where the system should choose among all the anonymized entities in the corresponding paragraph to fill in X.
body_sentences.182: The Stanford Question Answering (SQuAD) dataset is another recent machine comprehension test with over 500 Wikipedia articles and +100,000 crowdsourced questions.
body_sentences.183: The answer to every question in this dataset is a span of text from the corresponding reading passage.
body_sentences.184: Human accuracy on CNN/DailyMail is estimated to be around 75% (Chen et al., 2016) with the current state-of-the-art at 76.1 on CNN (Sordoni et al., 2016), and 75.8 on DailyMail (Chen et al., 2016).
body_sentences.185:
The human F1 score on SQuAD
dataset is reported to be at 86.8%, with the current state-of-the-art achieving 82.9%.
body_sentences.186: Given these statistics, neither of these datasets leave enough room for further research.
body_sentences.187: Given that in both these tasks the answer to the question is directly found in the provided passage, we argue that the community requires a more challenging MC task which goes beyond matching and needs some level of inference across passages.
body_sentences.188: The GuessTwo task requires basic reasoning and inference across paragraphs for comprehending various aspects of entities relative to one another.
body_sentences.189: Another interesting task is MCTest (Richardson et al.
body_sentences.190: ), which is a reading comprehension test with 660 fictional stories as the passage and four questions per story.
body_sentences.191: The human-level performance on MCTest is estimated to be around 90%, with the state-of-the-art achieving an accuracy of 70% (Wang et al., 2015).
body_sentences.192: MCTest is also proven to be challenging, however, given its very limited training data, further progress on the task has been hindered.
body_sentences.193: Yet another relevant QA task is the Allen AI Science Challenge (Clarke et al., 2010; Schoenick et al., 2016), which is a dataset of multiple-choice questions and answers from a standardized 8th grade science exam.
body_sentences.194: The questions can range from simple fact lookup to complex ones which require extensive world knowledge and commonsense reasoning.
body_sentences.195: This task requires machine reading of a variety of resources such as textbooks and goes beyond reading a couple of passages.
body_sentences.196: 8 Conclusion  We introduced the novel task of GuessTwo, in which given a short paragraph comparing two common entities, a system should guess what the two entities are.
body_sentences.197: The comparison paragraphs often have complex semantic structures which make this comprehension task demanding.
body_sentences.198: Furthermore, guessing the two entities requires a system to go beyond only understanding one given passage and requires reasoning across paragraphs, which is one of the most under-explored, yet crucial, capabilities of an intelligent agent.
body_sentences.199: So far, we have crowdsourced a dataset of more than 14K comparison paragraphs comparing entities from nine major categories.
body_sentences.200: For benchmarking the progress, we filter a collection of these paragraphs to create a test set, on which humans perform with an accuracy of 94.2%.
body_sentences.201:
For contin-
uing our data collection, we would like to have a targeted entity pair selection where we particularly collect the missing relations in our partial ordering lattice.
body_sentences.202: We believe that this process can help developing more effective systems.
body_sentences.203: For the most recent statistics of the dataset and the best performing systems please check this website.
body_sentences.204: We presented a host of neural models and a novel semantic-driven approach for tackling the task of GuessTwo.
body_sentences.205: Our experiments show that the semantic approach outperforms the neural models by a large margin.
body_sentences.206: The poor performance of the neural models we experimented with can motivate designing new architectures which are capable of performing basic reasoning across paragraphs.
body_sentences.207: The results strongly suggest that bridging the gap between system and human performance on this task requires models with richer language representation and reasoning capabilities.
body_sentences.208: As a future work, we would like to explore the feasibility of marrying our semantic and neural models to exploit the benefits that each of them has to offer.
